description: One week after the 2020 presidential election, Tina Barton, who as the clerk of Rochester Hills, Mich., oversaw voting there, sat down at her desk, coffee in hand, and listened to her voice mail messages.

title: Stabbing Attack in Sydney Kills at Least Six People
description: A man killed six people and injured at least 12 others during a stabbing rampage at a popular shopping mall in Sydney, Australia, on Saturday afternoon, in one of the country’s deadliest acts of mass violence in recent decades.

title: Don Wright, Editorial Cartoonist With a Skewer for a Pen, Dies at 90
description: Don Wright, a two-time Pulitzer Prize-winning editorial cartoonist whose pointed work punctured duplicity and pomposity and resonated with common-sense readers, died on March 24 at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 90.

title: The Sydney Mall Stabbing Rampage: What We Know
description: A stabbing attack on Saturday afternoon at a crowded mall in Sydney, Australia, left six people dead and at least 11 others injured, including a 9-month-old girl. The rampage was the deadliest act of mass violence in the country since 2017.

title: State Dept. Is Sending Its Top Diplomat for East Asia to China
description: The top U.S. diplomat for East Asia will travel to China on Sunday, the State Department announced, just days after President Biden met with the leaders of Japan and the Philippines in Washington as part of a broad diplomatic outreach in the region to counter China’s aggression.

title: Four South Dakota Tribes Bar Gov. Kristi Noem, Trump V.P. Contender, From Lands
description: Four of South Dakota’s federally recognized Native American tribes have barred the state’s governor, Kristi Noem — a Republican whose name has been floated as a potential running mate for former President Donald J. Trump — from their reservations. The latest blocked Ms. Noem on Thursday.

title: Inside Donald Trump’s Embrace of the Jan. 6 Rioters
description: Two days before former President Donald J. Trump was booked at an Atlanta jail on his fourth indictment, he held an event at his golf club in New Jersey for another group of people facing criminal charges: rioters accused of storming the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

title: Hudson Yards ‘Vessel’ Sculpture Will Reopen With Netting After Suicides
description: Nearly three years after a series of suicides shut down the Vessel, the 150-foot-tall centerpiece of the Hudson Yards complex in Manhattan, the project’s developer said on Friday that it would reopen this year with new safety measures.

title: Faith Ringgold Dies at 93; Wove Black Life Into Quilts and Children’s Books
description: Faith Ringgold, a multimedia artist whose pictorial quilts depicting the African American experience gave rise to a second distinguished career as a writer and illustrator of children’s books, died on Saturday at her home in Englewood, N.J. She was 93.

title: Indigenous Artists Are the Heart of the Venice Biennale
description: Before visitors step into any gallery at the 2024 Venice Biennale, which opens April 20, Indigenous artists will have made their presence known.

title: Representing the U.S. and Critiquing It in a Psychedelic Rainbow
description: People in Venice might hear the jingle dress dancers before they see them. On April 18, some 26 intertribal Native American dancers and singers from Oklahoma and Colorado will make their way through the winding streets and canals of the Italian city. Wearing brightly colored shawls, beaded yokes and dresses decorated with the metal cones that give the dance its distinctive cshh cshh rattling sound, they’ll make their way to the Giardini, one of the primary sites of the Venice Biennale. There, they’ll climb atop and surround a large red sculpture composed of pedestals of different heights and perform.

title: Stacks of Cash at Menendez Home Were Not From His Bank, Prosecutors Say
description: When Senator Robert Menendez was charged last year with corruption after investigators found $486,000 in cash stashed around his house in New Jersey, he offered a simple, “old-fashioned” explanation: It had been his custom to withdraw cash from a personal savings account to keep at home, a habit he learned from his Cuban immigrant parents.

title: Savings Plan
description: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

title: Tensions Flare in West Bank After Israeli Teenager Is Found Dead
description: The disappearance and death of an Israeli teenager, whose body was found on Saturday in the West Bank, spurred deadly rioting by Israeli settlers in Palestinian villages, ratcheting up tensions even further in the occupied territory.

title: Iran Launches Aerial Attack on Israel
description: Air-raid sirens sounded across Israel and the West Bank as the night sky lit up with incoming missiles and interceptions.

title: What Happened to Damages That O.J. Simpson Owed to the Victims’ Families?
description: More than 25 years ago, O.J. Simpson was found liable in civil court for the deaths of his ex-wife Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman, her friend, and was ordered to pay more than $33 million to their families.

title: U.S. Intercepts Dozens of Iranian Drones and Missiles Aimed at Israel
description: The U.S. military said that it had shot down dozens of the drones and missiles that Iran fired at Israel on Saturday, a strong demonstration that despite recent criticism of Israel’s conduct of the war in Gaza, Washington was firmly committed to protecting a key ally from Iran, a mutual adversary.

title: She Was Kidnapped a Decade Ago With 275 Girls. Finally, She Escaped.
description: Saratu Dauda had been kidnapped. It was 2014, she was 16, and she was in a truck packed with her classmates heading into the bush in northeastern Nigeria, a member of the terrorist group Boko Haram at the wheel. The girls’ boarding school in Chibok, miles behind them, had been set on fire.

title: Should We Change Species to Save Them?
description: For tens of millions of years, Australia has been a playground for evolution, and the land Down Under lays claim to some of the most remarkable creatures on Earth.

title: In Final Rally Before New York Trial, Trump Again Casts Himself as Political Victim
description: Two days before his first criminal trial was set to begin in Manhattan, former President Donald J. Trump on Saturday again framed the charges he faces as a broad attempt by Democrats to keep him from the White House, and he criticized a gag order placed on him by the judge in the New York case.

title: Quotation of the Day: Thousands Try to Run, or Swim Across ‘Death River,’ to Dodge the Draft
description: “Everybody is afraid to die, but we try to make them look at it from a different perspective.”

title: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Can’t Keep it Together
description: If an entire Oscars ceremony full of Barbenheimer jokes and a killer Ryan Gosling performance of “I’m Just Ken” didn’t give you sufficient opportunity to say goodbye to the pop cultural phenomenon of “Barbie,” “Saturday Night Live” is here to make sure that you’ve had Kenough.

title: Corrections: April 14, 2024
description: An article last Sunday about Bran­don Blackwell, who excelled on the British quiz show “University Chal­lenge,” misstated the name of the Los Angeles neighborhood where the College Bowl Company has its office. It is Woodland Hills, not Wild Hills.

title: Israel Faced a Sophisticated Attack From Iran
description: Late Saturday, Iran began firing hundreds of drones and missiles at Israel, including weapons that experts say are more sophisticated than anything Israel had encountered until now in six months of fighting with Hamas and its allies in the region.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: ‘I Opened the Book App on My Tablet and Began Reading’
description: Dear Diary:

title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: The Connections Companion No. 308
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Why Heat Pumps Are the Future, and How Your Home Could Use One
description: Heat pumps, which both warm and cool buildings and are powered by electricity, have been touted as the answer to curbing greenhouse gas emissions produced by homes, businesses and office buildings, which are responsible for about one-third of the emissions in New York State.

title: A Portrait Fit for a Publisher
description: A portrait of Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr., the publisher of The New York Times from 1992 through 2017, was unveiled April 4 at The New York Times headquarters in Manhattan. The subject himself tugged a crushed velvet drape off the painting, by Katy Schneider, to applause from several dozen guests.

title: At the Masters, Champions Past, Present and Future
description: Seventy-five years ago this past week, Sam Snead won the Masters Tournament and became the first champion to receive one of Augusta National Golf Club’s green jackets.

title: As Trial Looms, Trump Plays to a Jury of Millions
description: The first criminal trial of Donald J. Trump will begin on Monday, and the 45th president thinks he can win — no matter what the jury decides. Mr. Trump will aim to spin any outcome to his benefit and, if convicted, to become the first felon to win the White House.

title: After Stabbing Rampage, Australia Struggles With How and Why
description: On a perfect mid-autumn day, the scene at an upscale suburban mall in Sydney, Australia, was as humdrum as it was idyllic: mothers pushing strollers, gaggles of teenagers being young, families whiling away the weekend afternoon.

title: Fashion’s Favorite Farm
description: There are certain things the fashion industry will always love: The young and beautiful. Art and money. Nostalgia. A comeback. From time to time, it also loves to throw itself behind a cause.

title: S’mores Kits? Saunas? Short-Term Rental Hosts Scramble to Stand Out.
description: In Scottsdale, Ariz., where the sunny weather lures bachelorette party revelers year-round, short-term rental owners are ready and waiting.

title: Dana White, Donald Trump and the Rise of Cage-Match Politics
description: Dana White’s diplomatic ambitions were clear, if complicated: Un-cancel Bud Light.

title: For Caleb Carr, Salvation Arrived on Little Cat’s Feet
description: J. Alfred Prufrock measured his life out in coffee spoons. Caleb Carr has done so in cats.

title: Netflix’s New Film Strategy: More About the Audience, Less About Auteurs
description: Back in, say, 2019, if a filmmaker signed a deal with Netflix, it meant that he or she would be well paid and receive complete creative freedom. Theatrical release? Not so much. Still, the paycheck and the latitude — and the potential to reach the streaming service’s huge subscriber base — helped compensate for the lack of hoopla that comes when a traditional studio opens a film in multiplexes around the world.

title: This Prosecutor Pledged to Change George Floyd’s City. Her Critics Are Circling.
description: Mary Moriarty, a former public defender, became Minneapolis’s top prosecutor last year after persuading voters shaken by the murder of George Floyd that she could improve public safety by reining in police misconduct and making the criminal justice system less punitive.

title: Jan. 6 Obstruction Case at Supreme Court Could Help Trump and Many Others
description: At first blush, the case the Supreme Court will hear on Tuesday seems technical, requiring the justices to parse a decades-old statute mainly concerned with the destruction of business records.

title: At Milan Design Week, a Smorgasbord of Tables and Table Toppers
description: At Alcova, an annual Milan Design Week exhibition that celebrates the unconventional, an aptly named San Francisco studio named Surfacedesign is showing tables and other furniture pieces made from boulders. There is no end to the movable feast of materials that can be turned into tables, just as there is no end to the things you can put on them. The seemingly infinite options are further amplified by an urge to give new life to old, overlooked or discarded stuff.

title: Queer Women Behaving Badly: These Movies Scrap the Coming-Out Story
description: To a queer woman going to the movies, it may seem as if there has been something in the ether for the past year. First, in August, there was “Bottoms.” Then “Drive-Away Dolls” arrived in February. “Love Lies Bleeding” joined the fray in March. This cluster of relatively mainstream films about queer women, deliciously frothy and fun to watch, feels unprecedented.

title: Undergarments for the Ultrawealthy
description: In a subterranean workroom of a building on Rue Saint-Honoré in Paris, there are cabinets filled with bags of Chantilly lace in myriad shades: Yves Klein blue, sherbet orange, a silvery periwinkle. Nestled between the furniture are some half-dozen sewing machines, at which a small staff of seamstresses works while constructing corsets for Cadolle, a company that has been making custom lingerie for almost 140 years.

title: Lincoln’s Murder Is Often Re-enacted, but Not at Ford’s Theater
description: Since Ford’s Theater reopened as an active theater in 1968, it has rarely been the scene of a dramatic re-enactment of Abraham Lincoln being shot to death there on April 14, 1865.

title: As Trump Ponders V.P. Contenders, He Asks: Can They Help Me Raise Cash?
description: As former President Donald J. Trump sifts through potential running mates, he has peppered some advisers and associates with a direct question: Which Republican could best help him raise money for the rest of the presidential campaign?

title: How Women at One Arizona Clinic Are Grappling With the Abortion Ruling
description: Leah found out she was five weeks pregnant on the same day that the Arizona Supreme Court upheld an 1864 law banning nearly all abortions in the state.

title: Iran’s Attacks Bring Long Shadow War With Israel Into the Open
description: Follow live updates on Israeli military strikes in Iran.

title: Four Years Out, Some Voters Look Back at Trump’s Presidency More Positively
description: Views of Donald J. Trump’s presidency have become more positive since he left office, bolstering his case for election and posing a risk to President Biden’s strategy of casting his opponent as unfit for the presidency, according to a new poll by The New York Times and Siena College.

title: Immigrant Detention Should Have No Place in Our Society
description: In May 2018, Fernando Arredondo and his 12-year-old daughter, Andrea, reached the U.S.-Mexico border. The two had fled Guatemala after gang members killed his son, Marco, and threatened the rest of the family.

title: Stormy Daniels and the Comeuppance of Donald Trump
description: Sometimes I lie awake at night wondering whether Donald Trump is afraid.

title: The Sunday Read: ‘What I Saw Working at The National Enquirer During Donald Trump’s Rise’
description: At the center of the criminal case against former President Donald Trump in Manhattan is the accusation that Trump took part in a scheme to turn The National Enquirer and its sister publications into an arm of his 2016 presidential campaign. The documents detailed three “hush money” payments made to a series of individuals to guarantee their silence about potentially damaging stories in the months before the election. Because this was done with the goal of helping his election chances, the case implied, these payments amounted to a form of illegal, undisclosed campaign spending. And because Trump created paperwork to make the payments seem like regular legal expenses, that amounted to a criminal effort at a coverup, argued Alvin Bragg, the district attorney of Manhattan. Trump has denied the charges against him.

title: The Most Famous Golfer at the Masters Is Black. Why Aren’t There More Players Like Him?
description: When the Masters Tournament commenced on Thursday, featuring 89 competitors, there was exactly one Black golfer in the field: the one we all know, Tiger Woods. Beyond that, the field for the 88th Masters didn’t look all that different from the previous 87.

title: What Weapons Did Israel Use to Block Iran’s Attack?
description: Israeli forces used two main defensive weapons, the Iron Dome and the Arrow 3, to shoot down most of the more than 300 drones, ballistic missiles and cruise missiles fired at its territory by Iran, while others were shot down by the United States and other allies.

title: Biden Seeks to Head Off Escalation After Israel’s Successful Defense
description: President Biden and his team, hoping to avoid further escalation leading to a wider war in the Middle East, are advising Israel that its successful defense against Iranian airstrikes constituted a major strategic victory that might not require another round of retaliation, U.S. officials said on Sunday.

title: Iran Attacks Israel
description: Iran’s missile attack on Israel has ended, for now, and virtually none of the missiles reached their targets.

title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | April 15, 2024
description: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

title: Iran’s Strikes on Israel Open a Dangerous New Chapter for Old Rivals
description: Iran has retaliated directly against Israel for the killings of its senior generals in Damascus, Syria, with an onslaught of more than 300 drones and missiles aimed at restoring its credibility and deterrence, officials and analysts say.

title: What We Know About Iran’s Attack on Israel and What Happens Next
description: World leaders are urging Israel to act with restraint after Iran launched a large aerial attack over the weekend, firing at least 300 drones and missiles. Israel’s war cabinet has not yet said how it will respond to the first such direct assault launched from Iranian territory after decades of shadow warfare between the two countries.

title: The Atmosphere of the ‘Manosphere’ Is Toxic
description: To understand the state of men in this country, it’s necessary to know three things.

title: Do You Have a Family Story That Defines Who You Are?
description: American history is often recounted through major events. But every family has its own stories, moments that were perhaps never recorded in a history book — the purchase of a home, a hometown disaster, a death, a move — yet speak to the events that define the United States.

title: Rico Wade, an Architect of Atlanta Hip-Hop, Dies at 52
description: Rico Wade, an architect of Southern hip-hop who produced albums for rap acts including Outkast, Goodie Mob and Future, died on Saturday in Atlanta. He was 52.

title: An Unexpected Player in Israel’s Defense: Jordan, Home to Many Palestinians
description: The response by Israel and other nations to Iran’s aerial attack kept the majority of its drones and missiles from landing in Israel, ensuring they caused only light damage and a handful of injuries, Israeli officials said.

title: News Outlets Urge Trump and Biden to Commit to Presidential Debates
description: A group of major news organizations — including The Associated Press and the five big broadcast and cable networks — issued an unusual joint statement on Sunday urging President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump to commit to participating in televised debates before Election Day.

title: Spring Cleaning to Refresh; Bacon and Egg Don to Comfort
description: Good morning. The birds are back in town, chirping at dawn, flitting to and from the feeders set up out back, firing up the cat at the window. There’s no languorous idyll in bed before breakfast these days; there’s much to be done. Daylight’s burning. Time for spring cleaning.

title: The Beautiful World of Birding
description: To the Editor:

title: Strikes Upend Israel’s Belief About Iran’s Willingness to Fight It Directly
description: Iran’s unprecedented strikes on Israel this weekend have shaken Israel’s assumptions about its foe, undermining its long-held calculation that Iran would be best deterred by greater Israeli aggression.

title: American Pizazz Meets the Staid Traditions of Sumo
description: Two giant, shirtless men bow respectfully and then hurl themselves at each other in a violent pas de deux that ends with a victory in seconds.

title: At Carnegie Hall, Weimar Is Irresistible but Vaguely Defined
description: In the middle of Erich Wolfgang Korngold’s suite of incidental music for “Much Ado About Nothing,” there’s a march meant to accompany Dogberry, Shakespeare’s comic constable, and his fellow watchmen.

title: Iran Attack Tests Netanyahu’s Political Staying Power
description: In a deeply divided Israel, even the dramatic scene above the country’s skies on Sunday is open to political interpretation.

title: Review: Under Manfred Honeck, the Philharmonic Becomes One
description: In a thrilling concert of Russian staples on Friday night, the conductor Manfred Honeck unified the players of the New York Philharmonic using something we don’t often hear from the stage of David Geffen Hall: a distinct point of view.

title: Prince Harry Hits the Polo Field in Front of Netflix Cameras
description: In front of rolling cameras and a crowd of nearly 300 guests, Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex, barreled toward one end of a polo field in South Florida on Friday.

title: The Dystopian ‘Civil War’ Reaches No. 1 at the Box Office
description: Hollywood executives — not all, but most — have insisted for years that uncomfortable, thought-provoking, original movies can no longer attract big audiences at the box office.

title: Johnson Says the House Will Vote on an Israel Bill in the Coming Days
description: Speaker Mike Johnson said on Sunday after Iran’s overnight attack on Israel that the House would vote in the coming days on aid for Israel, and he suggested that aid for Ukraine could be included in the legislation.

title: Sununu Says Trump ‘Contributed’ to Insurrection, but Still Has His Support
description: Gov. Chris Sununu of New Hampshire said on Sunday that former President Donald J. Trump “absolutely contributed” to an insurrection and that Mr. Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election were “absolutely terrible” — but that nothing, not even felony convictions, would stop him from voting for Mr. Trump because the economy, border security and “culture change” were more important.

title: Iran Just Made a Big Mistake. Israel Shouldn’t Follow.
description: It would be easy to be dazzled by the way Israeli, American and other allied militaries shot down virtually every Iranian drone, cruise missile and ballistic missile launched at Israel on Saturday and conclude that Iran had made its point — retaliating for Israel’s allegedly killing a top Iranian commander operating against Israel from Syria — and now we can call it a day.

title: For Israel, Revenge Should Be a Dish Served Cold
description: After several days during which Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei repeatedly vowed that “the evil Zionist regime” would be punished for its April 1 attack on Iran’s embassy complex in Damascus that killed seven Iranian military advisers, including three top commanders, the Islamic Republic struck. More than 300 drones and missiles launched from Iranian soil took aim at Israel on Saturday. Nearly all of them were intercepted, mainly by Israeli or American defenses, with a report of just one Israeli casualty, a girl from a Bedouin community wounded by shrapnel.

title: ‘Sunset Boulevard,’ Heading to Broadway, Wins Big at Olivier Awards
description: A reimagining of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s “Sunset Boulevard,” starring Nicole Scherzinger as Norma Desmond, the long forgotten silent movie star who descends into madness, was the big winner at this year’s Olivier Awards, Britain’s equivalent of the Tonys.

title: Monday Briefing: Israel Weighs a Response to Iran
description: Calm mostly prevailed in Israel yesterday after Iran fired more than 300 missiles and drones at the country overnight. Nearly all were intercepted, Israeli military officials said, and those that made an impact caused only minor damage.

title: A 7-Year-Old Girl Is the Lone Serious Casualty of Iran’s Barrage
description: The hospital waiting room was quiet on Sunday: There was no crowd of relatives, no flood of patients. Israel’s air defenses had just fended off a large-scale Iranian attack, with only one serious casualty recorded.

title: Brightly Colored Rock
description: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

title: Palestinians Trying to Return to Northern Gaza Say Israeli Troops Fired on Them
description: As thousands of displaced Palestinians tried to return to their homes in northern Gaza on Sunday, Israeli troops shot into the crowd, forcing people to turn back in panic, according to an emergency worker and two people who tried to make the journey.

title: He Was Blinded in One Eye, but Salman Rushdie’s Vision Is Undiminished
description: Last May, nine months after the knife attack that nearly killed him, Salman Rushdie made a surprise appearance at the 2023 PEN America literary gala. His voice was weak and he was noticeably thinner than usual; one of his eyeglass lenses was blacked out, because his right eye had been blinded in the assault. But anyone wondering whether the author was still his old exuberant self would have been immediately reassured by the way he began his remarks, with a racy impromptu joke.

title: Quotation of the Day: Kidnapped With 275 Girls, She Finally Escaped
description: “The only crime of these girls was to go to school.”

title: No Corrections: April 15, 2024
description: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

title: Review: It’s No Sunday in the Park With ‘Lempicka’
description: Having dismissed her work as merely decorative, a fierce Italian gives harsh advice to an ambitious young painter: “You need to be a monster,” he brays. “Or a machine.”

title: Far Right’s Ties to Russia Sow Rising Alarm in Germany
description: To enter a secret session of Germany’s Parliament, lawmakers must lock their phones and leave them outside. Inside, they are not even allowed to take notes. Yet to many politicians, these precautions against espionage now feel like something of a farce.

title: Four Wild Ways to Save the Koala (That Just Might Work)
description: It was spring in Queensland, Australia, a season when many wild animals find themselves in trouble, and the Currumbin Wildlife Hospital was a blur of fur and feathers.

title: After Iran’s Barrage, Israel Questions What Might Be Next for the Gaza War
description: Within moments of Israel and its allies shooting down a fusillade of Iranian missiles and drones this weekend, many began wondering what the latest exchange between Israel and Iran would mean for the war in the Gaza Strip.

title: On Himalayan Hillsides Grows Japan’s Cold, Hard Cash
description: The views are spectacular in this corner of eastern Nepal, between the world’s highest mountains and the tea estates of India’s Darjeeling district, where rare orchids grow and red pandas play on the lush hillsides.

title: Monday Briefing
description: Israel showed signs that it would not immediately retaliate for the hundreds of exploding drones and missiles that Iran fired at it over the weekend, nearly all of which Israel and its allies intercepted.

title: With Iran’s Strikes, Arab Countries Fear an Expanding Conflict
description: Arab countries, from the United Arab Emirates and Oman to Jordan and Egypt, have tried for months to tamp down the conflict between Israel and Hamas, especially after it widened to include armed groups backed by Iran and embedded deep within the Arab world. Some of them, like the Houthis, threaten Arab governments as well.

title: Word of the Day: foolhardy
description: The word foolhardy has appeared in 26 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 31 in the book review “All That Glitters: A Fresh Look at the California Gold Rush” by W. M. Akers:

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: What to Know About Jury Selection in Trump’s Manhattan Criminal Case
description: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush money trial in Manhattan.

title: Prosecutors’ Error Exposes Potential Scope of Disgraced Detective’s Harm
description: In court papers they are called the “Scarcella Lists” — compilations of cases involving a retired New York City homicide detective whose problematic work on homicides in the 1980s and 1990s was cited in numerous wrongful convictions that have cost the city and state millions.

title: Roses Are Red, Love Is True. Here’s Why This Bouquet Costs $72.
description: To gather every last stem and ribbon, Mr. Patrikis is on the phone constantly, negotiating with 15 distributors to get the best deals.
Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: The Connections Companion No. 309
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Who Are Key Players in the Trump Manhattan Criminal Trial?
description: The first criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump is underway. Take a closer look at central figures related to the case.

title: Here are the latest developments.
description: Israel’s war cabinet met again on Monday as it faced growing international pressure not to retaliate against Iran for its missile and drone attack over the weekend, even as some far-right members of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government called for an aggressive response.

title: 2 Police Officers Are Killed in Shootout Near Syracuse, New York
description: Two police officers, who had been following up on a traffic violation, were killed in a shooting ambush on Sunday evening outside a house in an upstate New York town near Syracuse, the authorities said.

title: Three Daughters, Three New Memoirs About Mothers
description: Mothers rarely reveal themselves fully to their growing children. Who would it serve, after all, to pull back the curtain on the woman-in-charge and reveal a fumbling human? Like the Wizard of Oz, moms don’t always know how things work, but let’s not scare the kids.

title: The Sex Lives and War Deaths of Soldier Poets
description: It is chillingly plain that the young, fashionable English poet Rupert Brooke had romanticized the great bloodletting that was about to happen. “Come and die,” he wrote to a friend in 1915, during the first winter of World War I. “It will be great fun.”

title: Why Better Times (and Big Raises) Haven’t Cured the Inflation Hangover
description: In western Pennsylvania, halfway through one of those classic hazy March days when the worst of winter has passed, but the bare trees tilting in the wind tell everyone spring is yet to come, Darren Mattern was putting in some extra work.

title: Beyond Pizza and Yale: What to See, Eat and Do in New Haven
description: The 75-foot-long brontosaurus at the newly reopened Yale Peabody Museum in New Haven, Conn., is the same dinosaur that the natural history museum has had on display since 1931. Yet it looks different. A fresh pose. New front ribs. The head is repositioned at a more inquisitive angle. The museum’s four-year renovation not only refreshed the nearly 100-year-old building, but also included an overhaul of the fossil mounts that research has proved to be inaccurate.

title: The U.S. Has Received a Rare Invitation From China. There Is Only One Right Answer.
description: In the middle of the last century, as the United States and Russia rapidly amassed thousands of nuclear weapons, China stayed out of the arms race, focusing its energy on growing its economy and broadening its regional influence.

title: What Elective Do You Wish Your School Offered?
description: Does your school offer elective classes? Have you taken any? If so, which have been your favorite? Why?

title: How the Trumpeter Jeremy Pelt Became a Chronicler of Black Jazz History
description: The trumpeter Jeremy Pelt was sitting on his couch, browsing YouTube, when he decided to become an author.

title: Chinese Company Under Congressional Scrutiny Makes Key U.S. Drugs
description: A Chinese company targeted by members of Congress over potential ties to the Chinese government makes blockbuster drugs for the American market that have been hailed as advances in the treatment of cancers, obesity and debilitating illnesses like cystic fibrosis.

title: Norman Lear’s Art Goes to Auction
description: Norman Lear was best known for what he created on television, but he also appreciated the kind of art you can hang on the wall and collected his fair share over the years.

title: What’s Killing Endangered Sawfish in Florida?
description: Fishing guides in the Florida Keys began reporting unusual sightings to Ross Boucek last fall. Small bait fish, especially at night, would start spinning in tight circles in the water, seemingly in distress.

title: The Trump Trial: A Monumental Moment
description: Good morning. It’s Monday, and we’ll look at the kickoff of Donald Trump’s trial in Lower Manhattan and what it may be like to cover the proceeding.

title: How to Avoid One of the Deadliest Forms of Skin Cancer
description: When spring turns to summer and warm weather lures more people outside, skin cancer may be at most a distant concern. But experts said it’s important to take the risk seriously.

title: Can Trump Get a Jury Who Will Give Him a Fair Shake? My Expert Opinion Is Yes, and Here’s Why.
description: If Donald Trump has been clear about anything, it is this: “I cannot get a fair trial in New York.”

title: The 25 Best Restaurants in Boston Right Now
description: In the Where to Eat: 25 Best series, we’re highlighting our favorite restaurants in cities across the United States. These lists will be updated as restaurants close and open, and as we find new gems to recommend. As always, we pay for all of our meals and don’t accept free items.

title: How to Advocate for Yourself at the Dentist
description: Think about the last time you went to a dentist: Did you walk out feeling like your questions were answered, or did you wonder whether your provider was being straight with you?

title: Match Made in Venice: Tadao Ando and Zeng Fanzhi
description: An American institution sponsors an exhibition by a Chinese artist in collaboration with a Japanese architect at a centuries-old Venetian building.

title: What’s on TV This Week: The WNBA Draft and ‘RuPaul’s Drag Race’
description: For those who still haven’t cut the cord, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, April 15-21. Details and times are subject to change.

title: At Harlem Stage, Bringing Downtown Dance Uptown
description: Since the inception of Harlem Stage’s dance series E-Moves 25 years ago, that “E” has stood for several categories of artists: Emerging. Evolving. Established. But the series itself has always stood for one goal in particular: providing space and resources for artists of color to develop their work.

title: $1.8 Million Homes in California
description: In the late 1860s, Calistoga became a popular vacation destination for residents of San Francisco drawn by the fresh air and natural hot springs. Those hot springs and the surrounding resorts are still a draw, along with the area’s wineries and the hiking trails in Robert Louis Stevenson State Park, which ascend to the top of Mount Saint Helena, about 40 minutes from this property.

title: There Is a Part of Modern Life That Is So Essential Armies Should Never Attack It Again
description: In late March, after two years of withering attacks on Ukraine, Russia knocked out half of Ukraine’s power supply. Up to that point, Russia’s missiles and kamikaze drones had mostly targeted the Ukrainian substations that push electricity from power plants to consumers. But this time they hit the plants themselves, severely damaging and destroying hydroelectric and fossil fuel stations — all of which are difficult to repair or replace.

title: A Few Words About Nests
description: Spring is proceeding apace in this yard, despite my worst fears. For 28 of the 29 years that my husband and I have lived in this house, the elderly widow next door mostly shared our commitment to a natural yard. And because her house backed up to a little patch of woods, too, between us we managed to create a miniature wildlife sanctuary. I could sit outside in springtime and hold very still while a tufted titmouse pulled hairs from my head and carried them to her nest in the yard next door.

title: Should I Dress to Hide My Scars or Show Them Off?
description: In a world of Instagram filters, Photoshop, fillers, Botox, lasers and every other body treatment under the sun, it can be shocking to look at your actual untouched self. Marks that once signaled a life well lived — or adventurously lived, or dangerously lived, or joyfully lived; of pain experienced and conquered — can now seem a somewhat embarrassing sign of wear and tear, or human frailty. And no one wants to be giving worn-down vibes.

title: In the 2024 Race, Trump’s Trial Is About to Take Center Stage
description: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush money trial in Manhattan.

title: Questions About Assassinations Test the Limits of Trump’s Immunity Claim
description: “It is clear that as president, I will be bound by laws just like all Americans,” Donald J. Trump said in 2016, during his first campaign.

title: What I Found Inside the MAGAverse on the Eve of Trump’s Trial
description: On Saturday afternoon I drove out to eastern Pennsylvania, one of the big battlegrounds between President Biden and Donald Trump in this election, to attend Mr. Trump’s final rally before his criminal trial starts Monday. I was curious about the mood of Trump voters as this historic case gets underway. Were they feeling angry? Worried? Frustrated? Ready to go all civil war?

title: A Show of Might in the Skies Over Israel
description: Iran’s much-anticipated retaliation for Israel’s killing of senior military leaders produced a fiery aerial display in the skies over Israel and the West Bank.

title: U.S. Awards Samsung $6.4 Billion to Bolster Semiconductor Production
description: The Biden administration will give up to $6.4 billion in grants to Samsung, one of the world’s largest chipmakers, the latest in a slew of awards intended to shore up domestic production of cutting-edge semiconductors.

title: Taking a Moment to Lounge at Milan Design Week
description: A cruel irony of Milan Design Week, which runs until Sunday, is that it requires tremendous exertion; visitors must speed walk from booth to booth, and from showroom to showroom, if they hope to see even a fraction of the goods around town. And yet many compelling new products, like the chair, sofas and bed linens presented below, are about rest and relaxation. On the positive side, one usually can take a moment to sink into the displays to see just how comfortable they are. Ahh!

title: Making Art From the Unexpected at Milan Design Week
description: Designers are by definition manipulators — of materials, senses and expectations. There is nothing they like better than making the beholders of their creations stop in their tracks. At the Salone del Mobile, in a show devoted to emerging designers that runs through Sunday, visitors may be arrested by a cushion that resembles a big colorful, softball and sits like an egg in a nest of polished wood sticks. What is it? An ottoman, naturally. A few other eye catchers and head scratchers are presented below.

title: A Huge Number of Homeowners Have Mortgage Rates Too Good to Give Up
description: Something deeply unusual has happened in the American housing market over the last two years, as mortgage rates have risen to around 7 percent.

title: At Milan Design Week, the Power Is Often in the Collection
description: Milan Design Week, which runs through Sunday, allows companies, collectives or designers to express a unified point of view that transcends the attractions of any single product. All the hand-carved furnishings shown by Zanat, a company in Bosnia and Herzegovina, for example, reflect a dedication to craft that the owners inherited from generations of woodworking family members, though different international designers contributed to the group. This is just one of many examples found through the festival of collections augmenting the messages of their parts.

title: Online Dating After 50 Can Be Miserable. But It’s Also Liberating.
description: When my marriage collapsed after 23 years, I was devastated and overwhelmed. I was in my 50s, with two jobs, two teenage daughters, one dog. I didn’t consider dating. I had no time, no emotional energy. But then a year passed. One daughter was off at college, the other increasingly independent. After several more months went by, I started to feel a sliver of curiosity about what kind of men were out there and how it would feel to date again. The last time I dated was 25 years ago, and even then, I fell into relationships mostly with guys from high school, college, parties, work. Now every man I knew was either married, too young, too old or otherwise not a good fit.

title: Severe Storms Expected in the Plains and Midwest
description: Thunderstorms, damaging winds and large hail are expected in the Plains starting on Monday before moving across parts of Illinois, Iowa, Missouri, the South and the Midwest, the National Weather Service said.

title: Picking a Jury to Try Trump, and What’s Next for Iran and Israel
description: On Today’s Episode:

title: Iran’s Unprecedented Attack on Israel
description: Overnight on Saturday, Iran launched its first direct attack on Israeli soil, shooting hundreds of missiles and drones at multiple targets.

title: Trump’s Nostalgia Bump
description: President Trump left office wildly unpopular. But in the past few years, some voters’ opinions about him have improved. Support for how Trump handled key issues as president — including the economy, and law and order — has risen by about six percentage points since 2020, according to the latest New York Times/Siena College poll. A plurality of voters, 42 percent, now say the Trump years were “mostly good” for the country. Only a quarter say the same of President Biden’s tenure.

title: Oil Markets Shrug Off Iran’s Attack on Israel
description: Oil markets shrugged off the growing tensions in the Middle East, after Iran launched a barrage of missiles and drones against Israel over the weekend. On Monday morning, prices for Brent crude oil, the international benchmark, fell by about 1 percent, to $89.49 a barrel.

title: Pentagon Reviews Events Before Attack That Killed 13 U.S. Troops in Kabul
description: A new Pentagon review of the events leading up to the bombing that killed 13 American service members at the airport in Kabul, Afghanistan, in August 2021, has reaffirmed earlier findings that U.S. troops could not have prevented the deadly violence.

title: Salman Rushdie Reflects on His Stabbing in a New Memoir
description: “So it’s you,” Salman Rushdie remembers thinking on the morning of Aug. 12, 2022, as a black-clad man, a “squat missile,” sprinted toward him on an auditorium stage in Chautauqua, N.Y. Rushdie thought: “Here you are.”

title: Israel’s Allies Make a Full-Court Press to Urge Restraint
description: Israel’s allies on Monday were strongly urging it not to retaliate against Iran for the missile and drone attack over the weekend, calling instead for a de-escalation of the tensions that have gripped the Middle East.

title: Want to Win at Solitaire? Players Share Their Best Tips
description: In some countries, one of the many variants of Solitaire games is called Patience, and it’s an apt name. If this pastime teaches you anything, it’s how to keep from losing your cool while you cycle through the deck looking for that red six.

title: Markets Brace for Israel’s Next Move
description: Investors are breathing a sigh of relief on Monday. Global stocks are in the green and oil prices have retreated from last week’s gains after Iran’s unprecedented drone and missile attack on Israel was mostly neutralized in the skies. But the calm could be short lived, as world leaders and markets focus on Israel’s response.

title: Reeling From Mass Stabbing, Australians Ask: Was It About Hatred of Women?
description: Mary Aravanopoulos stood clutching her daughter, huddling for safety with about 15 other women in the dress shop filled with ethereal organza gowns. They had watched a man saunter past in the mall corridor, swinging a large knife in his hand back and forth.

title: We’re Adding to Our California Movie List
description: Because of reader recommendations, I recently had the pleasure of watching for the first time “Boyz N the Hood,” the 1991 coming-of-age story set in South Central Los Angeles.

title: A Video Game Made Out of Brick, Clay and Tenacity
description: A handmade video game sounds like an oxymoron, like a rock opera or a TV movie. But on rare occasions, designers choose to build their interactive worlds not from pixels and polygons but from physical materials like cardboard and clay.

title: Barry Diller Bets on Media Veterans to Turn Around The Daily Beast
description: The Daily Beast has long been an outlier in the digital empire of the billionaire Barry Diller. As sites like Match.com and Expedia made millions over the years, Mr. Diller’s digital tabloid lost money, publishing scoop after scoop but struggling to turn a profit.

title: The Fever Dream of Landing an Apartment
description: Felicia Russo says her friends tell her she seems calm. But she says she’s freaking out on the inside: Her housing search is keeping her up at night.

title: Stabbing of Bishop in Australia During Livestreamed Service Was Act of Terror, Police Say
description: A stabbing at a church in a suburb of Sydney, Australia, that left several people injured and unfolded during a livestreamed Mass was an act of terrorism, the authorities said on Tuesday.

title: Families of Manchester Bombing Victims File Lawsuit Against MI5
description: Hundreds of survivors of the 2017 Manchester Arena bombing attack have filed a lawsuit against the British government intelligence agency MI5, their lawyers said.

title: At This Hockey Game, the Biggest Save Might Have Kept a Boy Alive
description: Asia Davis was up late thinking about the harrowing finish to the hockey game the night before, and decided that she needed to find the man who might have saved her son’s life. So she went on TikTok.

title: Tesla Will Lay Off More Than 10% of Workers
description: Signs of turmoil at Tesla multiplied on Monday after the electric car company told employees it would lay off more than 10 percent of the work force to cut costs and two senior executives resigned.

title: A Slimmer Goldman Sachs Posts Hefty Jump in Profit
description: What a difference a year makes at Goldman Sachs.

title: Biden and His Allies Are Likely to Stay Quiet on Trump’s Manhattan Trial
description: As former President Donald J. Trump goes on trial on Monday in Manhattan, President Biden and his allies are not likely to say much.

title: Judge in Trump’s Criminal Trial Declines to Recuse Himself
description: Juan M. Merchan, the judge overseeing Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial in Manhattan, has declined to step aside from the case, rejecting the former president’s effort to delay the trial and attack his integrity.

title: The Snubs and Surprises of the 2024 Olivier Awards
description: On Sunday night, the Olivier Awards — Britain’s equivalent to the Tonys — took place in London. As expected, “Sunset Boulevard” took home the most trophies (and will have a Broadway run later this year), but there were also some surprise winners. Matt Wolf and Houman Barekat, The New York Times’s London theater critics, joined the reporter Alex Marshall to discuss the winners, the snubs and the last year in British theater.

title: Flying With Dogs or Cats? These Are Airlines’ Pet Policies
description: Flying with a pet can be expensive and confusing, with fees, weight limits, carrier size rules and the need to make sure there’s no loud barking (or meowing) on board.

title: Can You Find the 15 Book Titles Hidden in This Text?
description: This month’s Title Search puzzle challenges you to uncover novels written for middle-grade readers.

title: Why Your Big Sister Resents You
description: In a TikTok video that has been watched more than 6 million times, Kati Morton, a licensed marriage and family therapist in Santa Monica, Calif., lists signs that she says can be indicative of “eldest daughter syndrome.”

title: A Beyoncé Album Repeats at No. 1 for the First Time in 11 Years
description: Beyoncé’s “Cowboy Carter” holds at No. 1 for a second week on the Billboard album chart, fending off new releases from J. Cole and the K-pop group Tomorrow X Together.

title: One-Pot Tortellini With Prosciutto and Peas Is for Friends
description: I’ve just returned from visiting friends in the French countryside where we cooked together, improvising dinner from whatever looked promising at the market that day. This is my absolute favorite way to cook: in convivial company, riffing with what the season has offered, exchanging inspiration and knowledge as we go.

title: The Widest-Ever Global Coral Crisis Will Hit Within Weeks, Scientists Say
description: The world’s coral reefs are in the throes of a global bleaching event caused by extraordinary ocean temperatures, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and international partners announced Monday.

title: Politics Are Always Personal. In This Novel They’re Ruinous.
description: The titular spoiled heart of Sunjeev Sahota’s new novel is not spoiled in the sense of being overindulged. It is spoiled in the sense of being ruptured, through hardship. A tragedy in which a man comes to personal and profession ruin, the novel explores whether the ruination is self-inflicted or societal, and whether it is a degenerative condition or if some radical surgery can reverse it. Certainly, Sahota has a surgeon’s dexterous hands, and the reader senses his confidence.

title: A.I. Has a Measurement Problem
description: There’s a problem with leading artificial intelligence tools like ChatGPT, Gemini and Claude: We don’t really know how smart they are.

title: Validation for Woman Who Said She Was Raped in Australia’s Parliament
description: When a young former government employee said on national television in 2021 that she had been sexually assaulted in Australia’s Parliament two years earlier, it shocked the nation and unleashed a wave of anger aimed at the country’s insular, male-dominated political establishment.

title: With Nuclear Deal Dead, Containing Iran Grows More Fraught
description: When Iran agreed to a deal in 2015 that would require it to surrender 97 percent of the uranium it could use to make nuclear bombs, Russia and China worked alongside the United States and Europe to get the pact done.

title: In City Ballet’s Coming Season, New Works and Earlier Curtain Times
description: New York City Ballet’s 2024-25 season will feature earlier curtain times, fewer intermissions and a tribute to the great American ballerina Maria Tallchief, the company announced on Monday.

title: Faith Ringgold Perfectly Captured the Pitch of America’s Madness
description: Faith Ringgold, who died Saturday at 93, was an artist of protean inventiveness. Painter, sculptor, weaver, performer, writer and social justice activist, she made work in which the personal and political were tightly bonded. And much of that work gained popularity among audiences that didn’t necessarily frequent galleries and museums. This was particularly true of her series of semi-autobiographical painted narrative quilts depicting scenes of African American urban childhood, subject matter that translated readily into illustrated children’s books, of which, over the years, Ringgold published many.

title: Israel’s Choices on Response to Iran’s Attack All Come With Risks
description: As Israel’s leaders continued on Monday to mull a possible response to the massive Iranian aerial attack over the weekend, they faced several choices, all of which carry their own risks.

title: ‘A Different World’ Hits the Road to Help Historically Black Colleges
description: Picture a pampered socialite ostentatiously putting her generational wealth on display. Or an outspoken teenage activist leading a climate change protest. Or a charismatic opportunist luring people into his latest scam.

title: These Gay Novels Offer a ‘More Interesting Conversation’ About Faith
description: Near the end of Daniel Lefferts’s recent novel, “Ways and Means,” the protagonist — a gay and ambitious but disastrously wayward college student — takes an unexpected turn for a queer character: He finds salvation in God.

title: Ushio Amagatsu, Japanese Dancer Who Popularized Butoh, Dies at 74
description: Ushio Amagatsu, an acclaimed dancer and choreographer who brought worldwide visibility to Butoh, a hauntingly minimalist Japanese form of dance theater that arose in the wake of wartime devastation, died on March 25 in Odawara, Japan. He was 74.

title: Ready for a Chatbot Version of Your Favorite Instagram Influencers?
description: Being an influencer can be a lot of work. Instagram thinks A.I. can lend a big hand.

title: Al Gore Thinks Trump Will Lose and Climate Activists Will Triumph
description: Former Vice President Al Gore was in New York City over the weekend for a leadership training convened by the Climate Reality Project, his nonprofit organization.

title: ‘Access Hollywood’ Tape Won’t Be Played for Jurors in Trump Trial
description: The judge in Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial on Monday again refused to allow the infamous “Access Hollywood” tape to be played for jurors, but said that the comments Mr. Trump made on the tape could be introduced as evidence.

title: Keeping U.S. Power Behind Israel Will Keep Iran at Bay
description: Until Iran’s barrage of missiles and drones against Israel, the two countries had avoided open military intrusions into each other’s territory. Tehran most often acted through proxies, and Jerusalem via bombing runs and unacknowledged assassinations in the region.

title: A Radicchio Salad for People Who Don’t Think They Like Radicchio
description: At the start of this year, the celebrated Danish chef Frederik Bille Brahe, 40, closed down Apollo Bar & Kantine, his beloved art-world hangout in the courtyard of Copenhagen’s Kunsthal Charlottenborg, in order to reinvent the space and its menus. He and his executive chef, Yuta Kurahashi, 36, shifted their focus to dinner and now serve an evening meal of pared-back dishes that riff on seasonal ingredients. But if Bille Brahe likes to keep things simple, he also enjoys surprising his guests. The dish he calls Salada Rosso presents as an untouched head of radicchio but it is, in fact, a clever piece of trompe l’oeil: the chicory has been deconstructed, its bitter leaves coated with a rich, earthy black garlic and almond cream and a sweet citrus vinaigrette, then reassembled with chunks of tart blood orange tucked between them. Radicchio, Bille Brahe says, is a vegetable “most people think they don’t like — but then you make something with it that changes their minds.” Here, he shares the recipe.

title: A Beloved Copenhagen Cafe Gets Serious About Dinner
description: When the Danish chef Frederik Bille Brahe took over Apollo Bar & Kantine in 2017, it was an unassuming museum cafe where a person might grab a quick sandwich after seeing one of the contemporary art exhibitions at the Kunsthal Charlottenborg, set within the same grand 17th-century complex in central Copenhagen.

title: Straws That Don’t Cause Wrinkles. Wait — Straws Cause Wrinkles?
description: Maybe it’s the superior experience of sipping a crisp, carbonated beverage through a straw. Maybe it’s the rise of Stanley Cups, or the supremacy of cold brew even in the winter months. Whatever it is, straws have evolved beyond the single-use plastic straw-man argument for environmental personal responsibility into so much more.

title: Rico Wade and Organized Noize’s 10 Essential Songs
description: The Atlanta producer Rico Wade was the de facto leader of the Dungeon Family, the loose collective of rappers and musicians that coalesced around his mother’s smoke-filled Georgia basement — a.k.a. the Dungeon — in the mid-90s. Wade’s open doors and nurturing vision became the engine of Atlanta’s creative explosion, tilting the spotlight away from New York and Los Angeles and toward the homegrown sounds of artists like Outkast, Goodie Mob, Killer Mike, Janelle Monáe and eventually Wade’s younger cousin Future. Wade’s death at 52 was announced on social media last Saturday.

title: The Biden Guide to Dressing Younger
description: Joe Biden is a dapper guy. He always has been. When he turned up decades ago for a first date with the woman who would become his wife and the country’s first lady, her gut reaction was, “This is never going to work, not in a million years.”

title: Donald Trump on Trial: What to Expect
description: To the Editor:

title: Trump Media Stock Plunges 18%, Extending Recent Losses
description: Shares of former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company plunged on Monday after the company filed to register the potential sale of tens of millions of additional shares.

title: A Weary Trump Appears to Doze Off in Courtroom Ahead of Criminal Trial
description: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush money trial in Manhattan.

title: Iran’s Strike on Israel Creates Military Uncertainty, Diplomatic Opportunity
description: Follow live updates on Israeli military strikes in Iran.

title: Roberta Karmel, First Woman Named to the S.E.C., Dies at 86
description: Roberta Karmel, the first female member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, whose belief that the agency stymied legitimate business activities inspired philosophical combat with her colleagues, died on March 23 at her home in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. She was 86.

title: New York Nears a Housing Deal to Confront Affordability Crisis
description: New York state leaders have reached a deal on the framework of a legislative plan to address one of the worst housing crises in the nation, Gov. Kathy Hochul said on Monday.

title: ‘Rust’ Armorer Is Sentenced to 18 Months for Involuntary Manslaughter
description: The armorer on the film “Rust,” who loaded a live round into a revolver that went off on the set in 2021 and killed its cinematographer, was sentenced on Monday to 18 months in prison for involuntary manslaughter.

title: How to Make Frozen Shrimp Even Faster (and More Delicious)
description: My cousins and I used to dare one another to touch the shrimp, their 10 legs dancing, their antennae waving. At the Chinese seafood restaurants near us in the San Gabriel Valley of Southern California, the servers would bring our orders, still alive, to the table for approval before taking them into the kitchen. In Cantonese cuisine, feisty fish and crustaceans are prized for their delicate freshness.

title: David Egilman, Doctor Who Took On Drug Companies, Dies at 71
description: Dr. David Egilman, a physician and expert witness who, over a 35-year span, gave testimony in some 600 trials involving corporate malfeasance, resulting in billions of dollars in awards for victims and their survivors, died on April 2 at his home in Foxborough, Mass. He was 71.

title: Ukraine Sees ‘Hypocrisy’ in Western Allies’ Defense of Israel
description: For people in eastern Ukraine, where nightly barrages of drones from Russia outpace the military’s overwhelmed air defenses, the response by Western allies to Iran’s aerial assault against Israel this weekend produced uncomfortable comparisons.

title: To Fight Climate Change, We Need New ‘Political Technologies’
description: Science alone won’t stop the planet from overheating. But science coupled with political science just might.

title: Britain’s Leaders Condemn Iran’s Attacks but Urge Israel to Show Restraint
description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain on Monday combined a strong condemnation of Iran’s weekend attack on Israel with a call for restraint from “all sides,” adding that he was working with allies to lower tensions in the region.

title: Transgender Veterans Sue V.A. Over Gender-Affirming Surgeries
description: An advocacy group for transgender veterans has filed a lawsuit over the failure of the Department of Veterans Affairs to provide or pay for gender-affirming surgeries.

title: A Surprising Shadow Was Created by the Total Solar Eclipse
description: Viewers of last week’s solar eclipse were treated to stunning celestial phenomena up and down the event’s path during totality. But those who watched it from Montreal saw a pair of additional surprises in the half-hour before and after the eclipse, when the moon obstructed the sun on April 8.

title: Robert Beerbohm, 71, Dies; Pioneering Comic Book Retailer and Historian
description: Robert Beerbohm, who in the 1970s helped start the first comic book chain stores and then, after a flood wiped out inventory in his warehouse, became a professed archaeologist of comics history, died on March 27 at his home in Fremont, Neb. He was 71.

title: Our Reporter on the Problem of New York City Trash
description: Is this how one of the world’s greatest cities still deals with garbage? Larry Buchanan, one of the New York Times reporters who walked miles around the city pondering trash for this story, explains what will be required to take New York’s trash bags off the street.

title: What Do You Want to Know About Trump’s Trial in New York?
description: The case against Donald Trump in New York is tawdry, consequential and deeply confusing. There are 34 complicated charges. A cast of notorious witnesses. Some extraordinary political implications.

title: New Migrants Get Work Permits. Other Undocumented Immigrants Want Them, Too.
description: Sam Sanchez, a Chicago restaurateur, was incensed when President Biden announced last September that his administration would extend work eligibility to nearly half a million Venezuelans, many of them migrants who had recently crossed the border illegally.

title: Protesters Block Roads Across the U.S. to Support Those in Gaza
description: Pro-Palestinian protesters shut down traffic Monday morning in cities across the country, part of a global effort to disrupt economies and pressure world leaders to push for a cease-fire in the Gaza Strip.

title: Expert Panel Calls on Germany to Legalize Abortion in First 12 Weeks
description: A government-appointed commission in Germany recommended on Monday that lawmakers legalize abortion during the first trimester of pregnancy, a move that could push the country into a long-avoided debate on an issue that for decades remained in a legal gray zone.

title: Supreme Court Poised to Cut Back Scope of Anti-Corruption Law
description: The Supreme Court seemed ready on Monday to limit the reach of a federal statute that makes it a crime for state and local officials, along with institutions that receive federal money, to accept gifts and payments meant to influence or reward their actions.

title: NPR C.E.O. Faces Criticism Over Tweets Supporting Progressive Causes
description: Katherine Maher, the chief executive of NPR, is facing online criticism for years-old social media posts criticizing former President Donald J. Trump and embracing liberal causes.

title: The Case for (and Against) the Fussy Dinner Party
description: Two editors make the case for keeping an at-home event simple or going all-out, with menus to match.

title: Lessons From a 20-Person Polycule
description: How they set boundaries, navigate jealousy, wingman their spouses and foster community.

title: Lebanese Official Blames Israel’s Spy Agency for Killing Near Beirut
description: A Lebanese money changer hit with U.S. sanctions over his alleged role as a financial middleman between Hamas and Iran was found shot to death at a villa just outside Beirut, Lebanon’s state news agency reported.

title: Tuesday Briefing: Donald Trump’s Trial Begins
description: Jury selection began yesterday in New York City, where Donald Trump faces charges that he falsified business records to cover up a sex scandal while serving as president. It is the first criminal trial of a former U.S. president, and the first of four indictments that Trump faces in the coming months.

title: E.V. Sales Are Slowing. Tesla’s Are Slumping.
description: As sales of Teslas drop and demand for electric vehicles cools — even as more models enter the market — an increasing number of automakers are competing for a slice of a shrinking pie.

title: James Dean, Founding Director of NASA Art Program, Dies at 92
description: James Dean, a landscape painter who ran a NASA program that invited artists like Robert Rauschenberg, Norman Rockwell and Jamie Wyeth to document aspects of the Mercury, Gemini and Apollo projects, died on March 22 in Washington. He was 92.

title: ‘The Stranger’ Review: Somewhere Over the Freeway
description: “The Stranger” is a tense if tidy thriller that chronicles a ride-hail driver’s journey to surveillance hell and back. Her survival against all odds mirrors that of the movie itself: The film’s footage originally premiered in 13 short-form episodes in 2020 on the streaming service Quibi, several months before it shut down.

title: A Historic Day
description: A year after Donald Trump was indicted, and after months of legal skirmishes and a torrent of attacks directed at key players in his case, the former president went on trial today.

title: 15 Looks That Did the Most at Coachella
description: There was no shortage of celebrities onstage last weekend at the first installment of this year’s Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in Southern California, where Doja Cat, Billie Eilish and even Will Smith performed.

title: Supreme Court Clears Way, for Now, for Idaho to Ban Transgender Treatment for Minors
description: The Supreme Court temporarily allowed Idaho on Monday to enforce a ban on gender-affirming treatment for minors, effectively suggesting that some justices appear comfortable with wading into another front in the culture wars.

title: Patti Astor, Doyenne of New York’s Avant-Garde Scene, Dies at 74
description: Patti Astor, the downtown Manhattan “It” girl, indie film star and co-founder of Fun Gallery, the scruffy East Village storefront space that in the early 1980s nurtured young graffiti artists like Futura2000, Zephyr, Lee Quinones, Lady Pink and Fab 5 Freddy, as well as showcasing artists like Keith Haring, Kenny Scharf and Jean-Michel Basquiat, died on April 9 at her home in Hermosa Beach, Calif. She was 74.

title: Prospective Jurors Are Dismissed in Dozens as Trump’s Trial Begins
description: Follow today’s live coverage of Trump’s hush money trial.

title: Owners of Funeral Home With Decaying Bodies Are Charged With Covid Relief Fraud
description: A couple arrested last year after at least 190 bodies were found decomposing at their Colorado funeral home were arrested again on Sunday on federal charges that they fraudulently obtained more than $880,000 in pandemic relief money, which they spent on vacations and personal goods, according to the F.B.I. and court records.

title: Trump’s Criminal Trial Begins With a Bumpy Jury Selection
description: New York prosecutors joined Donald Trump and his attorneys today in a Manhattan courtroom for the official start of the first criminal trial of an American president. Trump is facing 34 felony counts of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal during his 2016 campaign. If convicted, he could face up to four years in prison.

title: Day 1 of Trump’s Criminal Trial: Five Takeaways
description: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush money trial.

title: Philharmonic Sidelines 2 Players It Tried to Fire for Misconduct
description: The New York Philharmonic said on Monday that two players it had tried to fire in 2018 — but was forced to rehire after the musicians’ union challenged their dismissal — would not take part in rehearsals or performances for the time being after a magazine article detailed the allegations of misconduct that had been made against them.

title: Maurice El Medioni, Pianist Who Fused Jewish and Arab Music, Dies at 95
description: Maurice El Medioni, an Algerian-born pianist who fused Jewish and Arab musical traditions into a singular style he called “Pianoriental,” died on March 25 in Herzliya, on Israel’s central coast. He was 95.

title: Hochul Announces $237 Billion Budget, Including a Housing Deal
description: New York State leaders have agreed on the outline of a $237 billion state budget that includes a sweeping package aimed at stemming one of the worst housing shortages in the nation.

title: NASA Seeks ‘Hail Mary’ for Its Mars Rocks Return Mission
description: The cost of a proposed NASA mission to gather rocks on Mars and return them to Earth is spiraling upward and slipping further into the future. So on Monday, space agency officials asked for ideas on simplifying the mission and trimming its price tag.

title: Bidens Report Earning $620,000 and Paying $181,000 in Taxes in 2023
description: President Biden and Jill Biden, the first lady, reported earning roughly $620,000 in 2023, releasing their joint tax return for the third straight year of Mr. Biden’s presidency and the 26th time throughout his political career.

title: Atlantic City Mayor Accused of Beating and Punching His Teenage Daughter
description: The mayor of Atlantic City, N.J., Marty Small Sr., and his wife, La’Quetta Small, the superintendent of Atlantic City’s public schools, have been accused of physically and emotionally abusing their teenage daughter, officials announced on Monday.

title: Johnson Says House Will Vote on Stalled Aid to Israel and Ukraine
description: Speaker Mike Johnson on Monday said he planned this week to advance a long-stalled national security spending package to aid Israel, Ukraine and other American allies, along with a separate bill aimed at mollifying conservatives who have been vehemently opposed to backing Kyiv.

title: Israeli Settlers Kill 2 Palestinian Men in the West Bank, Officials Say
description: Israeli settlers fatally shot two Palestinians in the West Bank on Monday, according to Israeli and Palestinian officials, as tensions continued to spike in the Israeli-occupied territory.

title: Audit Questions Purchase of $19,000 Lectern by Arkansas Governor’s Office

description: It was about 2:30 on Monday afternoon when the first 96 potential jurors filed into a drab courtroom in Lower Manhattan to encounter the world’s most famous defendant: Donald J. Trump.

title: Boeing Defends Safety of 787 Dreamliner After Whistle-Blower’s Claims
description: Boeing sought on Monday to reassure the public of the safety of its 787 Dreamliner plane days before a whistle-blower is scheduled to testify before Congress about his concerns regarding the jet’s structural integrity.

title: Under Pressure From Trump, Arizona Republicans Weigh Response to 1864 Abortion Ban
description: Facing mounting pressure to strike down a near-total abortion ban revived last week by Arizona’s Supreme Court, Republican state legislators are considering efforts to undermine a planned ballot measure this fall that would enshrine abortion rights in the Arizona Constitution, according to a presentation obtained by The New York Times.

description: The Chinese economy grew more than expected in the first three months of the year, new data shows, as China built more factories and exported huge amounts of goods to counter a severe real estate crisis and sluggish spending at home.

title: Trump, Trailing Biden in Cash, Relies on Big Donors to Try to Catch Up
description: Former President Donald J. Trump leaned heavily on major Republican donors in March as his campaign and the Republican Party sought to close the financial gap separating him from President Biden, new federal filings showed on Monday.

title: Microsoft Makes High-Stakes Play in Tech Cold War With Emirati A.I. Deal
description: Microsoft said on Tuesday that it would make a $1.5 billion investment in G42, an artificial intelligence giant in the United Arab Emirates, in a deal largely orchestrated by the Biden administration to box out China as Washington and Beijing battle over who will exercise technological influence in the Persian Gulf region and beyond.

description: It was so close. Had just one missile or drone gotten through and killed a lot of Israelis, American officials feared, the region could have gone up in flames.

title: In Australia, ‘Cats Are Just Catastrophic’
description: Katherine Moseby wanted to be clear: She does not hate cats. “They’re a wily beast,” she said, as her truck rumbled down a desert road. “But I respect them. They’re pretty incredible animals. Amazing hunters. Very smart.”

description: Speaker Mike Johnson said that he planned to advance a long-stalled national security spending package this week to aid Israel, Ukraine and other U.S. allies, coupled with a bill to mollify conservatives opposed to backing Kyiv.

title: Corrections: April 16, 2024
description: An article on Friday about the possible impact that psychedelics could have on survivors of the Oct. 7 terror attacks in Israel misspelled the surname of psychology professor at the University of Haifa. He is Roee Admon, not Edmon. The article also misspelled the given name of a cognitive science professor at the school. He is Roy Salomon, not Roi.

title: Germany’s Leader Walks a Fine Line in China
description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany tried to strike a delicate balance on a trip to China this week, promoting business ties with his country’s biggest trading partner while raising concerns over its surge of exports to Europe and its support for Russia.

description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

description: Since February thousands of pro-Palestinian activists have tried in vain to get the Venice Biennale, one of the world’s most prestigious international art exhibitions, to ban Israel over its conduct of the war in Gaza.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

description: Four months after an explosive congressional hearing on antisemitism precipitated the resignations of two Ivy League presidents, another university president is about to step to the hot seat.

title: Salt
description: Do you pay attention to the amount of salt in everyday foods? Do you think you are consuming too much?

description: Hundreds of thousands of people are homeless. This filmmaker wants you to see them.

title: How to Turn a Bike Ride Into a Bike Workout
description: There’s no better way to take in a perfect spring day than from a bike. The songbirds are back, the daffodils are blooming and your dusty 10-speed is looking for a rider.

title: Parenting in a Pandemic, and Other Tales of Woe
description: Reading Gillian Linden’s “Negative Space,” I kept thinking of the Lydia Davis story “Fear.” The story opens with a woman running out of her house, “face white and overcoat flapping wildly.” “Emergency, emergency,” the woman says. In the next sentence, Davis tells us that “nothing has really happened” to this woman, but still the community comes out to comfort her. “Fear,” like Linden’s novel, grapples with an amorphous sense of something coming, threatening; it situates the reader inside a world in which awful things exist but nothing, really, has happened yet. In the meantime, the world around both the woman in Davis’s story and the one in Linden’s novel mostly wants her to be quiet.

title: A Tale of Four Troubled and Talented Sisters, Told With Irish Flair
description: Caoilinn Hughes’s exuberant third novel opens with Olwen Flattery, a geology professor, lecturing her undergraduate students about tectonic convergence. “Just imagine the force it would take to move a mountain! And we’re not talking about violent, sudden processes, like an earthquake shouldering up a mountain range. No. These forces are so incremental and immense, so imperceivable and unstoppable, that there’s no halting their progress.”

title: When a Family’s Dysfunction Mirrors a Nation’s
description: When Nelson Mandela was released from Victor Verster Prison in 1990, after 27 years of incarceration, there was hope in the air. He and his wife, Winnie, raised clenched fists in triumph as they emerged from the prison gates, surrounded by supporters of different races. His release heralded a South Africa on the verge of transformation. The promise of a new rainbow nation drove masses in 1994 to the first inclusive general elections, but 30 years on, South Africa is floundering with power cuts, a tanking economy and xenophobia.

title: ‘Shogun’ Episode 9 Recap: an Army of One
description: It’s a deception by which even the ingenious Lord Toranaga would be impressed. Step one: Spend several episodes of your prestige-drama period piece touting “Crimson Sky,” a battle plan for an all-out assault on a medieval castle the brutality of which frightens even Toranaga himself.

title: Criminalizing Homelessness Won’t Make It Go Away
description: If you live in one of America’s cities, you probably see homeless people all the time. You might pass them on your way to work. Maybe you avoid eye contact. If they ask you for money, maybe you pretend you didn’t hear, and walk on by.

description: Follow live coverage of the Jan. 6 obstruction case at the Supreme Court.
