description: Twelve departing lawmakers tell us what Congress is really like.

title: What Was Your Most Frustrating Experience in Congress?
description: Twelve departing lawmakers tell us what Congress is really like.

title: Is Congress Corrupt?
description: Twelve departing lawmakers tell us what Congress is really like.

title: What’s One Word You Would Use to Describe Congress?
description: Twelve departing lawmakers tell us what Congress is really like.

title: 12 Departing Lawmakers Tell Us What Congress Is Really Like
description: These are their exit interviews.

title: Our Reporter on Broadway’s Big Week
description: Broadway is in the midst of a rolling celebration. In nine days, 12 shows opened. Michael Paulson, theater reporter for The New York Times, explains how and why all these shows are rolling out the red carpet.

title: Cows Are Just an Environmental Disaster
description: A decade ago, I was feeling pretty pessimistic about climate change. The politics of mitigating global warming just seemed impossible: asking people to make sacrifices, or countries to slow their development, and delay dreams of better, more prosperous lives.

title: How Do You Fix Congress?
description: Twelve departing lawmakers tell us what Congress is really like.

title: What Worries Members of Congress the Most About the Future?
description: Twelve departing lawmakers tell us what Congress is really like.

title: What Should a Congress Member’s Salary Be?
description: Twelve departing lawmakers tell us what Congress is really like.

title: Stream These 10 Movies Before They Leave Netflix in May
description: Two markedly different Adam Sandler vehicles are among the noteworthy titles departing Netflix in May, along with an unsung family treat, a pair of crisp psychological thrillers and the other dark sitcom from the co-star of “It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia.” (Dates indicate the final day a title is available.)

title: What to Know About the Police Shooting in Charlotte
description: A shootout that broke out on Monday when a team of law enforcement personnel tried to serve warrants to a suspect in Charlotte, N.C., left four officers dead and another four injured.

title: Europe’s Economic Laggards Have Become Its Leaders
description: Something extraordinary is happening to the European economy: Southern nations that nearly broke up the euro currency bloc during the financial crisis in 2012 are growing faster than Germany and other big countries that have long served as the region’s growth engines.

title: Walmart Introduces a New Store Brand for ‘Quality Food’
description: When prices for grocery staples surged in 2021 and 2022, some Americans who had not regularly shopped at Walmart increasingly turned to the retailer, which is known for its affordable prices. Now, the company is trying to keep those new customers and attract others with a new selection of plant-based, gluten-free and deluxe culinary fare.

title: Columbia Protesters Occupy Building, and Trump Complains About His Lawyer
description: On Today’s Episode:

title: The Secret Push That Could Ban TikTok
description: American lawmakers have tried for years to ban TikTok, concerned that the video app’s links to China pose a national security risk.

title: Blinken Arrives in Jordan to Discuss Aid for Gaza
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken arrived in Jordan on Tuesday for his second stop on a Middle East tour to meet with top officials to discuss the war between Israel and Hamas, which is roiling the region and the political landscape of the United States.

title: Child Killed in London Sword Attack, Police Say
description: One child was killed and several other people were hospitalized after a man with a sword went on a stabbing spree in northeast London early Tuesday morning, the authorities said.

title: A Q&A About Latino Republicans
description: Many people have been surprised by the shift of Latino voters toward the Republican Party. It has happened during the same decade that Donald Trump took over the party, and Trump often derides immigrants, including Latinos. Nevertheless, Latino support for Republicans has risen:

title: Meta Faces E.U. Investigation Over Election Disinformation
description: Meta, the American tech giant, is being investigated by European Union regulators for the spread of disinformation on its platforms Facebook and Instagram, poor oversight of deceptive advertisements and potential failure to protect the integrity of elections.

title: Police Arrest 25 Protesters at Cal Poly Humboldt, Ending Building Takeover
description: Police officers arrested 25 protesters early Tuesday and ended the occupation of an administration building that forced a campus shutdown at California State Polytechnic University, Humboldt.

title: Paramount Faces a Mountain of Questions
description: The boardroom intrigue at Paramount Global — the drama that has gripped the corporate world — just got messier.

title: Women on Bumble No Longer Have to Make the First Move
description: As the sheen on dating apps dulls, more Americans are reporting bad experiences on them. Frustrated by bots, subscription costs and high effort-to-reward ratios, Gen Z is fleeing the apps in hope of real-life meet-cutes. Earlier this year, “Bustle” declared that dating apps are in their “flop era.”

title: Tony Awards Nominations 2024: The Complete List
description: Follow our live updates on the Tony Awards nominations.

title: Weekly Student News Quiz: College Protests, School Lunch, Bird Flu
description: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

title: Ralph Lauren Invites Everyone to Return to (His) Office
description: Having mixed feelings about return to office? Not sure what to wear? Ralph Lauren has a solution for that.

title: Getir, a Rapid Grocery-Delivery Service, Exits the U.S. and Europe
description: Getir, the rapid grocery-delivery company that boomed during Covid lockdowns, said it was ending its operations in the United States and Europe, a major retreat by another pandemic darling.

title: 150 People Sue, Saying They Were Abused as Minors in N.Y.C. Custody
description: It had been a tumultuous year for Mary Soto, a high school freshman. She had been in and out of juvenile courts and struggling with her home life when an altercation with a police officer outside a party about 15 years ago led to her being held in custody at Horizon Juvenile Center in the Bronx.

title: California’s Population Grows for the First Time Since 2020
description: Three years ago, as Covid-19 ravaged the nation, California’s population did something it had not done in the state’s recorded history: It fell.

title: Killer Asteroid Hunters Spot 27,500 Overlooked Space Rocks
description: A couple of years ago, a team of researchers dedicated to finding killer asteroids before they kill us came up with a neat trick.

title: Hamas and Fatah Officials, Longtime Rivals, Met in China
description: Officials from Hamas and Fatah, the main Palestinian factions that have long competed for power in Gaza and the West Bank, met in Beijing recently for what Chinese officials on Tuesday called “in-depth and candid talks on promoting intra-Palestinian reconciliation.”

title: Daniel Radcliffe Is Nominated for ‘Merrily We Roll Along’
description: The Boy Who Lived is finally the Actor Who Got Nominated (for a Tony).

title: Green Girl Glory: Three Former Elphabas Scored Tony Nominations
description: The Green Girls are making good.

title: College Democrats Back Protests and Criticize Biden’s Israel Policy
description: College Democrats of America, the student organization of the Democratic Party, endorsed pro-Palestinian campus protests on Tuesday and called on President Biden to support a permanent cease-fire in Gaza.

title: Judge’s Contempt Punishment Takes Aim at Trump’s Tendency to Lie
description: The judge overseeing Donald J. Trump’s criminal case in Manhattan held him in contempt on Tuesday, fining the former president $9,000 for repeatedly violating a gag order and warning that he could go to to jail if he continued to attack witnesses and jurors.

title: Read the Judge’s Contempt Ruling
description: Justice Juan M. Merchan determined that Donald J. Trump violated a gag order barring him from attacking witnesses and the jury.

title: Columbia Protesters Rename Hamilton Hall to ‘Hind’s Hall’
description: The banner that protesters unfurled at Columbia University’s Hamilton Hall late Monday night read “Hind’s Hall,” a tribute to Hind Rajab, a 6-year-old Palestinian girl who was killed in Israel’s war against Hamas in Gaza.

title: ‘Smartphones on Wheels’ Draw Attention From Regulators
description: In the American imagination, car keys and a driver’s license have long represented freedom, autonomy and privacy. But modern cars, which have hundreds of sensors, cameras and internet connectivity, are now potential spying machines acting in ways drivers do not completely understand.

title: U.S. Plan to Protect Oceans Has a Problem, Some Say: Too Much Fishing
description: New details of the Biden administration’s signature conservation effort, made public this month amid a burst of other environmental announcements, have alarmed some scientists who study marine protected areas because the plan would count certain commercial fishing zones as conserved.

title: Judge Says Trump Can Attend Son’s High School Graduation in Florida
description: The judge in Donald J. Trump’s hush-money trial said Tuesday that the former president can attend the high school graduation of his youngest son, Barron, in Florida next month.

title: Walmart Is Shutting Health Centers After Plan to Expand
description: Walmart, the world’s largest retailer, said Tuesday that it was shutting down its health care centers, a network that only last year it said it planned to expand.

title: Meet the Men Who Eat Meat (and Only Meat)
description: “Girl dinner” this is not.

title: 8 Daily Newspapers Sue OpenAI and Microsoft Over A.I.
description: Eight daily newspapers owned by Alden Global Capital sued OpenAI and Microsoft on Tuesday, accusing the tech companies of illegally using news articles to power their A.I. chatbots.

title: Princeton University Art Museum Gets Six Site-Specific New Works
description: Princeton University has a long history of commissioning public art by the likes of Henry Moore, Louise Nevelson, Alexander Calder and Pablo Picasso, dating back to the 1960s. And when the Princeton University Art Museum opens to the public next year, at almost double the size of its original building, six new large-scale works by women and artists of color will have pride of place — visible beacons near the building’s perimeter, both indoors and out at this central crossroads on campus.

title: In Reversal, Expert Panel Recommends Breast Cancer Screening at 40
description: Citing rising breast cancer rates in young women, an expert panel on Tuesday recommended starting regular mammography screening at age 40, reversing longstanding and controversial guidance that most women wait until 50.

title: Less-Is-More Miso Roasted Salmon
description: Eric Kim has just written a luminous essay about Japanese breakfast, with its constellation of small savory dishes (rice, miso soup, fish, pickles), and the daily practice of preparing it. You could make it bespoke every day, but the more pragmatic approach is to cook some of the elements ahead and fill out the meal with leftovers and other scraps from the fridge — “cooking for future you, not present you,” as Eric says, an idea I love and one you can embrace for any meal.

title: Millions of New Yorkers Wait to Hear How Much Their Rent Will Go Up
description: Officials in New York City will soon decide how much rents are allowed to go up across nearly one million rent-stabilized apartments.

title: The Prevalence of Standing Ovations
description: To the Editor:

title: Mali Claims Death of Terrorist Who Helped Lead Deadly Ambush in Niger
description: Mali said on Monday that it had killed a high-value Islamist commander who helped lead a 2017 attack in which four American and four Nigerien soldiers were killed alongside an interpreter.

title: R.F.K. Jr.’s Campaign Says He Will Be on California Ballot
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. will be on the presidential ballot in California, his campaign said Monday, having secured the nomination of the American Independent Party, a minor party with a history of insurgent independent candidacies: Its first presidential nominee, in 1968, was the Alabama governor and segregationist George C. Wallace.

title: Trump Again Vows Mass Deportations and Won’t Rule Out Political Violence
description: Former President Donald J. Trump told Time magazine in an interview published Tuesday morning that if elected in November, he would deploy the U.S. military to detain and deport migrants, hedged on the possibility of political violence after the 2024 election and said he would permit states to decide whether to prosecute those who violate abortion bans.
